Sir,

I am enclosing accounts of Angus Bell, Cashier, Allan MacArthur, and Mr. Johnston. These are in connection with the school for building a new chimney, and you will notice at the bottom of Mr. Bell's account $4.00; this is for making a sand table. I had the chimney built when Mr. Johnston was up there doing some mason work on the agency house. It will be remembered that when I wrote the Dept about this work Johnston told me it would not cost more than $200 but when he finished the work it cost $400 more, but of course it would not stop before it was finished and I trust the Dept will honor the accounts.

Your obedient servant,

C.E. Parker
Indian Agent

October 17, 1911
Ottawa, December 19, 1911.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant and of plans and specification for a water supply at the Cape Croker Indian village.

You submit four alternative schemes A.B.C. and D. It is noted that the difference between A. and C. and between B. and D. are very small, consisting practically in the difference of cost in the intake.

It is also noted that you make a wide difference between the excavation required for a three inch pipe and that required for a one inch pipe. The excavation required in either case is the same. The only difference in cost between the systems is the difference between the cost of the two different pipes.

A three inch pipe is larger than necessary and a one inch pipe is too small to be used as a main under almost any circumstances;

Your plans and specifications have been returned to you by registered mail. Please amend them in the following particulars:

1. The main pipe to be two (2) inch galvanized iron. To be not less than four (4) feet below the surface of the ground.
2. Service pipe to be 5/8 inch instead of half inch and lead pipe instead of galvanized iron.
3. Plan No. 2 for the intake to be adopted.

A. D. Huether, Esq., C.E.,
Wiariton,
Ont.

Agreement made in duplicate the 19th day of September A.D. 1912.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And

Gilpin Brothers of the town of Warton in the province of Ontario (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the stone school-house and teacher's residence to be erected on the Cape Croker Indian Reserve.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the thirty-first day of December A.D. 1912.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of five thousand eight hundred dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further cov-nants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whosoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

July 28th 1922

Sir,

I beg to inform you of a leakage around the chimney of roof of #1, Cape Croker school.

Ottawa, August 1, 1922.

Sir:-

Replying to your letter of the 28th ultimo, I beg to say that you may purchase the cement required and have the leakage repaired around the chimney of the Cape Croker Indian Day School. The expenditure incurred for this work should be kept down to the lowest possible point.

When these repairs have been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the amount involved for the cement and labour. This matter should be attended to at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:

I beg to report to the Department I am in receipt of a school requisition from Miss Burke, of the No. 1, Cape Croker School, which includes supplies for school lunches, etc., and I hereto enclose this for the Department.

In connection with the school lunches, Miss Burke has asked me to request the Department, if it would be possible to periodically have a loaf of bread and a pound of butter supplied, to supplement the present school lunch supplies. She states this would be for benefit of pupils who come quite a distance to school, and who at times bring no noon meal, depending on the school lunch.

In my own estimation, this procedure seems hardly practical, as it is to be feared that soon none of the pupils would bring any noon meal with them, and the school pupils would then entirely be depending on the school lunch supplies.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of Departmental letter No. 8-1-5, dated July 10th, inst., regarding the condition of the cellar of the residence of the Cape Croker Indian Day School.

It appears that Miss Burke is under the impression that repairs to the cistern were done last year, which was not so. Miss Burke asked last year to have the cistern thoroughly cleaned, when work was done. In my opinion, the present condition is caused from the overflow of the cistern, after a rain, causing the cellar floor to be frequently damp. This condition can be helped again by having the cistern drained and cleaned, and patching it inside, also repairing the overflow pipe. It is impossible to entirely prevent damp on the cellar floor as, after heavy rains, the water seeps through under the foundation. The same conditions exactly exist here in the cellar of the Agency residence.

To entirely prevent this condition at the School, would incur a very heavy expense, as a drain would have to be dug outside the foundation of the school, as outlet for the surplus water.

To repair the cistern, and the overflow pipe, would cost around the sum of $10.00., and in my opinion, Indian labour would be quite suitable for this work.

Ottawa, December 2nd, 1935.

Dear Miss Burke,

With reference to your letter of the 20th ultimo, I would point out that the grant for prizes at Christmas is paid from the Appropriation for Indian Education and, consequently, the Indians have no authority to decide what amount can be allowed. Mr. Poste is being written today and informed that $10.00 will be allowed for this purpose at the Cape Croker Indian Day School. This is the same amount as was provided last year and is all that the Department can allow.

We have just received the enclosed requisition from you. A number of the items have been ordered from the Government Stationery Office and should reach you in the near future. With reference to your other requests, I would point out that our appropriation is limited and that the demands are many. We have received strict instructions to keep expenditures to the lowest possible point between now and the close of the fiscal year on March 31st, next. I would, therefore, appreciate your again reviewing this requisition with a view to deleting the articles which are not absolutely necessary. While the Department wishes you to be comfortable, I think you will realize that, in view of the many demands that we receive, it is not possible to grant all requests, especially in view of the fact that strict orders have been received to keep down expenditures.

Yours truly,

As the fence around the Cape Croker School has been constantly repaired during the last few years, I find that the present fencing is really about worn out, and in my opinion it would be much more economical to build next Spring, an entirely new fence around the school grounds. I have made a careful estimate, re. wire fencing, etc., and labour required, and a new fence would cost approximately, about $100.00, and if it is possible, I beg to recommend that this be done.

August 15, 1936.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have been rather worried over the Cape Croker school. Anyone who has a skeleton key can enter. I ordered a Yale lock but it had not come when I left July 3. Will you please authorize Mr. Poste to purchase one and see that it is put on the front door. I also ordered a padlock for the large gate. If it is not padlocked the gate will be left constantly open and the splendid new fence will be of no avail.

The school pumps are both out of order half the time. I would suggest that the man who sunk the pump would come and repair it. He lives near the reserve and examined it just before I left.

The toilets have not been repaired. The doors do not stay closed, the boxes are gone to pieces and the pits are not deep enough to accommodate the number now attending. I think Mr. Game reported this before. Nothing has been done about it.

Since the new fence was built one of the gates was dispensed with. As a result the people climb over the fence and break the wire. I suggested to Mr. Poste that one or more styles be built but he seemed to think it would be too expensive. Will the Department consider having this done? I think one of the Indians could do the work. Otherwise the fence will be torn in no time.

I have been taking rather a heavy course since July 6th in Toronto. There seems to be a general tendency to get away as far as possible from anything that was formerly considered O.K. in the teaching system.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Mr. J.D. Sutherland,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, August 24, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Miss Burke, teacher of the Cape Croker Indian Day School, with reference to certain repairs that are required at the school.

Please purchase a new Yale lock and have it put on the front door. A padlock is also required for the large gate.

Miss Burke states that the school pumps are out of order. The cost of repairing these will, no doubt, be reasonable, and you should arrange to have this work done before the school reopens.

If the toilets have not been repaired, you should also arrange for this at once.

Miss Burke also states that since the new fence was built one of the gates was dispensed with and, as a result, people climb over the fence and break the wire. Would it not be possible to have one or two stiles built at a reasonable cost?

Sir:

I beg to report to the Department that, while recently supervising some repair work at the Port Elgin Day school on the Cape Croker Reserve, I found that the eavestroughing around the building was rotted, and in a very bad condition, this considerably deteriorating the building.

In consequence of this, I beg to recommend that, subject to the approval of the Department, this eavestroughing be re-placed by new material and the work done during this summer vacation. I have obtained an estimate of the cost of the work, to include labour and material, and it would be around the sum of $14.00.

In addition to the above mentioned requirements, I beg to report that at this School also, I find there are two large holes in the ground at corners, caused from the faulty eavestroughing, where the water has been pouring in when rain occurs, which probably cause damage to the foundation, and these should be filled in with gravel. In my opinion, this work is urgent, and should be done as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Ind. Affs.
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 15th instant which refers to the bats in the attic of the Cape Croker No. 1 School I would refer you to the instructions contained in the last paragraph of official letter of July 22, 1937 addressed to Mr. Poste.

As stated in that letter you should hire one or more Indians to kill the bats that are in the attic, clean the attic thoroughly and see that there are no holes where other bats can enter. This matter has been brought to the Department's attention on several occasions in the past and I hope that you will make a determined effort to avoid any repetition. The manner suggested of disposing of these bats is the only reasonable one which you can follow in view of the fact that poisoning them would involve considerable danger to the person spreading the poison.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of Oct. 4th and regret misinterpreting your remarks. I understood that either the salary of the janitor would be increased or a small grant would be made for special work done in connection with the school grounds.

The special tasks mentioned were: Hauling across the yard and piling in the basement twenty-five cords of furnace wood and twenty cords of kitchen wood; moving, raking and setting the school grounds; Ploughing, harrowing and discarding the school garden.

The janitor gave his work up.
the sweeping, scrubbing, furnace work etc in connection with the janitor work of the school.

The agent is here at present. We discussed having the children do some of the work to lessen expenses but we both anticipate trouble from the parents if the children are asked to do much.

Mr. Suffnell agrees with me that a grant covering the extra expenses would be necessary in this particular case.

Trusting I have not encroached too far on your valuable time

Respectfully yours,

Suffnell

Indian Agent

Solic J. Burke
Sir;-

I beg to report to you motion #8 passed by the Cape Croker council at their regular meeting held here October 11th, Chief and all councillors present.

Moved by P.C. Nadjiwon A. Jones that we authorize our agent to write to the Department in detail as to the condition that No. 1 school is overcrowded with pupils and that our council feels that an extension class room is required or another building for such purpose, also to inform the education department to send a man and look over the situation and have another teacher appointed in order to teach the kindergarten class.

Cd.

Note—; I beg to report to the Department that the above motion was passed at the council meeting in regards to No. 1 school being overcrowded. At the present time the teacher has on the roll 48 pupils she seems to find it hard to do justice to the beginners with so many classes to teach. In order to have another teacher there would have to be another class room added.

I would be glad to be advised by the Department in regards to the above motion.

The Secretary,

Ottawa.

Ottawa, February 8, 1939.

Dear Sirs:

I have your letter of the 4th instant and thank you for the information supplied but I would be pleased if you would elucidate the statement,- "This $1.00 allowance represents a discount of 10% granted on all purchases, excepting Meats and Groceries, made through the D.A."

During the past couple of months we have received three small refunds from your store, 10% discount on D.A. accounts. The purchases were made by teachers in Indian Schools owned by the Department. Is this the reason that the discount was allowed or is it allowed on all D.A. accounts when the Department makes payment?

I would like to be in a position to know when it is in order to deduct the 10% discount and consider that this can only be satisfactorily arrived at by you marking the discount on the accounts.

I have before me a number of D.A. accounts from one of your Branch stores which have been paid by the Department at their full face value, no evidence of a 10% discount appearing on the accounts but before requesting a refund I would like to have a full explanation of the discount in question.

I also notice that on January 28, 1939, your store was forwarded cheque No.78254, for $26.80, in payment for a cook stove supplied an Indian of the Golden Lake Reserve, Ont., the letters "D.A." appeared on the account form but no number. Are we entitled to a refund of $2.68?

Any information you can supply will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

L.W. McCutcheon
Chief Treasury Officer.

Dear Sir:

Re: Allowance on Institutional Accounts.

Acknowledging receipt of your letter of March 22nd, we explained in our letter of the 11th instant that the 10% allowance on purchases through the Department of Indian Affairs applied only to purchases ordered through our Toronto Store or Mail Order Department, with the exception of provisions on which no allowance is granted.

We are referring the matter to our Treasury Department for a ruling in regard to the 10% allowance on purchases made through our Moncton, Brantford, Sault Ste Marie, Winnipeg and Edmonton Branch Stores.

You will hear further from us in the course of a few days.

Sir:

Moved by P.C. Nadjiwon and W. Lamorandiere that we requisition the sum of $30.00 for the purpose of expending such sum towards Christmas presents for the three Reserve schools, money to be divided in proportion to the number of pupils attending each school.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant enclosing bacteriological report of the water in the well at the Cape Croker No. 1 Indian Day School. The following is a simple method of water purification:

A level teaspoonful of chloride of lime should be rubbed into a teacupful of water. This solution should be diluted with three cupfuls of water and a teaspoonful of the whole quantity added to each two-gallon pailful of drinking water.

This will give .4 or .5 parts of free chlorine to a million parts of water, sufficient to destroy in ten minutes all typhoid and colon bacilli or other dysentery producing organisms in the water. Moreover, all traces of the chlorine will rapidly disappear.

The method of purification has been tested with Toronto Bay water inoculated with millions of bacteria. Every germ has been destroyed, and it has been unnecessary to boil the water.

The above information should be given to the teacher and she can purify the water used by the pupils of the school.

Sir:

I beg to report to the Department that the roof at No 1. Cape Croker Indian Day School is leaking badly; I have had this repaired several times but it does not stop the leaks what is really needed is an entirely new roof if it is not soon done all the plaster on the inside will drop off.

The steps going into the boy's entrance are also in need of repair as they are giving away from the building and new ones will have to be erected.

Ottawa,
October 7, 1944.

Mr. F.W. Tuffnell, Indian Agent, R.R. #5, Wiarton, Ont.

On requisition dated September 30 from the teacher of the Cape Croker Day School she states that the basement pipes and outside drain pipes should be overhauled. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Agent

Our furnace is in a poor condition; the grates are broken and there is no way of regulating the draught. Owing to this defect our furnace wood was consumed by mars. and we have been using wet cordwood and coal since. Added to this, it is most inconvenient. The opening is so low that one had to kneel awkwardly to feed it. As furnace wood is usually heavy, the work is back-breaking at times. Mr. Gamble and Mr. Duffield both agreed last fall that a new furnace would not be an unnecessary expense. Could one be installed before I leave for vacation?

Our basement has been flooded since March. The pipes and drains may be clogged. Will permission be given to have the basement cleaned, lined, and the pipes and drains cleared?

Sadi Burke,
Teacher.
Regarding the furnace at No.1 Cape Croker School mentioned by the teacher I have looked it over and find it is beyond repairing and would only be an added expense and in my opinion a new furnace is badly needed.

With reference to the basement flooding I do not think this is any fault with the drains as the water gets away after the spring floods and I have the same trouble with the basement at the Agency,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 5th, 1947.

Mr. F.W. Tuffnell, Indian Agent,
R.R. #5, Wiarton, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant, please let me know the make and size of the furnace at present in the Cape Crocker No. 1 School, so that we can place an order for a new one.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

I have just sent in my resignation from Cape Croker School so that a little word of explanation to you will not be amiss.

As stated by you in a former letter most of the household effects are my personal property. I corresponded with Miss Bonnath about the matter and we decided it would simplify matters & leave all at school property.

When Miss Marie took charge she found some articles had disappeared chiefly sheets, pillow cases and towels, of which I had a good supply as I had from bride & furnished for drifted kept quite who lived at a distance.

Sir,

I am writing to you on behalf of the Indians to get rid of Mr. Jones at once. He is a most immoral man also a liar, and not fit to teach the minds of young children.

I am an English woman married to an Indian here Joseph Copas and proud of it, but I hear from white people on all sides the remark "Jessey you marrying an Indian simply because of immoral drunkards like this one about the Indians as a race are a cheaper breed of people than whites, another thing I wish to complain about."

Oct 29th

NOV 8 1821
I have 5 children attending school here. I am bound to send them here as there is no other school. They are clean minded English boys, but the conduct of Mr. Jones won't keep them clean long. A few weeks back I had occasion to go see Mr. Jones. As he punished three of my children I called them thieves because a certain child named Raymond Breuille (a white child, son of the store keeper, great friend of Jones) lost his knife. He stole a child's book etc., but as he kept where in the room he attacked them. When I went to them about it—of course he did not like it—and told the whole school if it had been a man he would...
Have kicked his ass at the school a nice remark to make to children. The other day my boy Norman found a horse shoe in the road his child Brunelle accused him of taking it & told me of my first boys that if he did not return it she would give him an hiding. My boy is 9 & his Brunelle 13, he hit my boy & was parted by an Indian. My eldest boy was so mad he went down to give Eric by a hiding. When he saw him coming he got away. I ordered him away. Next morning when my child Norman (who I might kill for a knaps medal boy) went to school he ordered him out & to go only my children but to the Indians.
Children as well he pays them
no attention what ever. Simply
teaches these Brunelle children
so he can please the mother. I
inquired of different Indian children
about my boy coming home & they all
say that Jones said he dismissed
him from the school. Where all
the mother in the vicinity was with
Mrs. Robert Marsden Jones & his
own lips told me he was fond
of her. I am sure there is not a
cleaner or straighter woman on
the Island than Mrs. Robert Marsden
& it's a shame a worthless drunk
like this man should cause
this woman's character to be
taken away from her also to
his & wreck a good name.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Mrs. J. Coppegog, a white woman married to an Indian, at Christian Island, and also a resolution of certain members of the Christian Island band. Both these communications, the latter of which is signed by forty-one Indians, are referring again to the moral character and general unfitness of Mr. Thomas Jones, the teacher of the Christian Island school. It is strongly recommended that this man be dismissed.

Under date of the 14th ultimo the Department wrote to you explaining that it was not the intention to ask for the resignation of Mr. Jones, without further information from you as to his improper conduct. Under the same date I wrote to Mr. Jones, asking him to exercise more care and requesting him to answer my communication. I have not heard from him, and I am satisfied that, if the statement of behaviour alleged in the communications to hand today is true, this matter should be taken up again immediately.

Would you make a detailed report concerning this man and his activities, immediately. I would be pleased, also, to hear from you as to the standing of this Mrs. J. Coppegog and of Mr. Albert Menague (Councillor). It appears from the hand-writing of the resolution that it was prepared by this last named Indian.

As a rule the Department pays little attention to complaints that do not originate with our agent in the field, but this matter seems to be persistent and must have a grain of truth. We cannot afford to hire the services of a teacher for an Indian day school if there is any question as to his moral calibre. Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 14th, etc., received, contents noted. I beg to say in view of the report made to the Department as to my conduct on the Island and not aware of any such underhand work in progress. I am much regret that such went to headquarters for as far as I was concerned as you intimated a little ago and take should have settled this. I beg to say that was the course I took when I found my mistakes and as this occurred last July, I thought this was settled when the party involved accepted my apology and during holidays. I gave the people to understand that I had other openings and desired to know.
from them as to whether they are needing my services any longer which was as the Dept. is aware they requested me by a resolution in Council to stay another term and consequently adjusted matters for another term I am glad to note in your letter the lenient way you are dealing with me and will bear in mind my position more closely and I must say that from that date mentioned there has been nothing in my conduct that anyone could say against me and am in friendly terms with everyone. Of course I want the Dept. to understand me that I am doing my work just as faithfully as ever and it has been my highest ambition in my life to help educate my people believing that this is the best way to help them to an
even footing on the progress of time, and I believe, my record at your office will confirm my idea, since I have sacrificed the best part of my life in the service of Education my people not for the salary that is in it but I feel I owe this to them, probably I should not have written my own personal ideas but I feel I am writing to one who feels the same as I do.

Lastly I am sorry I erred but it has been a splendid lesson for we are all subject to mistakes and mine must be foremost. I assure you that you will never again have any reason to feel that I am not conducting myself civilly. In closing I regret to note that Mrs Jones is mentioned in this matter for there is no one on this Island that can say...
truthfully anything against Mrs. Jones as to her conduct and relationship with the people she comes in contact with and as you are aware that such a matter of false report in order to discredit one's character is a serious offence and in view of this fact after consideration I have convinced Mrs. Jones to leave the matter stand as it is.

I hope I have not bored you with this letter and I hope I have made clear to you my future intentions as to myself.

Hoping to hear from you.

Remain your humble servant,

Dear Dr. Manning:

Since writing to you on the 27th ultimo, concerning the Christian Island Indian Day School, I have had a visit from certain influential members of the Indian Band, and we have discussed at some length the future of the day school at that point. May I review the facts, to refresh in your mind the situation.

Previous to 1915, the Methodist Missionary Society were represented on the reserve at Christian Island by a Mr. Oliver, who taught in the day school. This gentleman was not wholly satisfactory to the Indian population as a teacher, for the simple reason that his duties were too manifold and his energies were too often bent in other directions. At the time of his resignation, the Indian Council took upon themselves the appointment of the school teacher, and they have been more or less successful in supervising the school activities.

The present incumbent - a Mr. Jones - has been so careless in his actions outside of the classroom that this Department has had to call for his resignation. I believe, at the time of my last writing on this matter, that the solution was to return again to the missionary-teacher type.

The recent delegation to Ottawa from the Indian Band at Christian Island has been the cause of the change in the Department's policy for this particular school. There is a general unrest among the Indians of Ontario, and this Department has had to use considerable tact in all its relations with the individual bands. I have to inform you that I have made arrangements for a teacher at the Christian Island Indian Day School, in conjunction with the Indian Council at that point. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant enclosing a communication from Chief Henry Jackson, of Christian Island, regarding a special council meeting held by the band, in which they have re-appointed Mr. Thomas Jones to the position of Teacher of the school on that reserve for the next school year.

In reply I beg to say that the Indians have been informed, through Chief Jackson and the Agent, that the Department could not consent to the re-engagement of Mr. Jones. His conduct during the past year was such as led to considerable friction among the different factions on the reserve. We gave the Indians an opportunity to appoint another teacher and suggested the names of two Indians who have the necessary qualifications and would be competent to fill the position. Our agent informs us that Chief Jackson tried to convince the Department that it would be better for the Council to engage the teacher he just wanted to get a chance to keep Jones in spite of the rest of the band.

As this school is conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Missionary Society, we have requested Rev. Dr. Manning, General Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Methodist Church, to nominate a missionary teacher for Christian Island. He informs us that he is endeavouring to find a suitable man. The matter of the appointment of a teacher is now in the hands of the authorities of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church.

We feel that the re-engagement of Thomas Jones would only lead to further friction among the members of the band. We hope that, in the course of a short time, the Church Authorities will be successful in securing a teacher and, if his qualifications are satisfactory, we will approve of his appointment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir;-

RE CHRISTIAN ISLAND.

I have an application from ENOS T. MONTOUR for the position of Missionary Teacher on Christian Island Indian Reserve.

The Rev. James Drew wrote me concerning him, and among other things said:

"This young man certainly has the gift of teaching. He taught school on the Six Nations Reserve and also in the New Credit School. He is a Local Preacher of some two or more years' standing, and also has been recommended as a suitable candidate for the ministry of our Church. He spent last year at Wesleyan College, Montreal. I have made enquiries about him and from the men who have known him from his earliest days there is the feeling that he would be just the man you need for the work. I know his father and brothers, and I also have learned from others that his home life is above the average Indian's home. He spent some four years under Mr. McVitty at Muncey, and his record there was a good one."

I wrote to Mr. McVitty, enquiring about him and this morning have a reply in which he says:

"Enos Montour spent about four years here. One of the best boys we ever had. Since leaving here he has studied at Brantford Collegiate. Every report has been favorable."

Prof. Graham, of Wesleyan Theological College, Montreal, says:

"Mr. Montour is a very gifted young Indian from the Brantford Reserve. He is a fluent speaker and uses good language, and has a good comprehension of the fundamentals of our faith. He is a very interesting young man, and, I think, would be acceptable to the congregations of any mission field, or other field, for that matter."

If you will agree to his appointment, I will notify him at once. Although I am not sure that he is now available, I ask you to agree to his appointment, so that if he is available no time will be lost in making the appointment. He wrote me on the 30th of June and I am sorry to say that, owing to uncertainty about his address,
it has taken us a good while to gather the information which I give you above.

If he is not available I think I know another man whom we could secure for the position, but Montour impresses me as being likely to make the greater success of the work at Christian Island.

Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Faithfully yours,

C.E. Manning

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter #6-1-1, bearing date of June 29th, re the request of the Indian Council at Christian Island that the teacher who may be appointed for the Indian Day School there, may have no missionary duties.

I beg to say that we have been urged again and again by the officials of our Church there to appoint a Missionary Teacher to their field, and I am not convinced that we ought to be influences in regard to this matter by the Indian Council, many of whom may be altogether indifferent to the work of the Church.

To send a Missionary there - who would have nothing to do but the work that usually falls to a Missionary on such a field - would be to give him less than a man's job, and would involve very heavy expense, which in these days of financial stringency we want to avoid.

I am now in correspondence with several young men, with teachers' qualifications, each of whom has had experience in school teaching and who would, if appointed to Christian Island, be willing to conduct services for the Indians on Sundays. I hope to be in a position in a few days to submit to you a statement of the qualifications of the one whose appointment I would recommend.

The Missionary Teachers at Moraviantown, Alderville and Gibson are, I understand, giving great satisfaction both to the Indian Department and to the Indians themselves, and I am satisfied that if we had an equally efficient teacher at Christian Island, as anyone of the three referred to, the Indians would be well satisfied with the arrangement.

I cannot but feel that to be governed by the request of the Council, to which you refer, would not be in the best interests of the Indians on Christian Island, and inasmuch as you have already agreed to the appointment of a Missionary Teacher at Christian Island, as previous correspondence goes to show, I think...

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Christian Island Agency.

The Day School was still closed during the week of September 3rd. I understand Mr. Cowling, Missionary Teacher, was attending a conference in Toronto. From all I could learn there does not appear to be much progress being made in this school. There seems to be quite a bit of dissatisfaction among the Indians with the work of Mr. Cowling. I had a number of complaints made to me regarding his methods of disciplining the pupils. It is reported that he is in the habit of taking the boys by the chin and back of the head and lifting them off their feet. One girl, daughter of the Truant Officer, had her knee injured by being thrown against a desk. It is also stated that he is impatient and quick tempered with the pupils. The Agent informed me that the pupils are backward in their studies. There is no Manual training or needlework taught; nothing to vary the routine studies or make classroom work attractive. Mr. Cowling is about 70 years of age and I understand is a very fine type of a Christian gentleman but his position built upon the fact that the Indians towards him, his usefulness as a teacher of Indian children is over. This school has a roll of 53 pupils and requires a younger teacher. I have no hesitation in recommending that Mr. Cowling be replaced by a younger and more energetic teacher with a sympathetic understanding of Indian boys and girls, one who would bring leadership and encouragement among the young people on the reserve. There is a splendid field for such a teacher, male or female.

Sir,

From recent conversation with Mr Robert Cowling, United Church Missionary, and Day School teacher, of the Reserve, I understand it is his intention to submit his resignation during the coming summer.

This being the case, and with the future welfare of the Indian people in view, I wish to take this early opportunity of asking the Department, if when the occasion arises and a new appointment has to be made, will they kindly give consideration to the selection of a Missionary-Teacher who has a Second Class Certificate, and is also qualified to teach Manual Training. A married man, not over middle age, who's wife would be willing to reside on the Reserve, and who would be interested enough to take an active part in social work and moral welfare of the Indian people.

I beg to state, the reason I am making this request is, with reference to the teaching of manual training in the school, I consider that under existing conditions on Christian Island, better results would be obtained from the pupils if this subject were included in their every day studies.

The Indian children of this Reserve are naturally backward in education, and I attribute this fact to the conditions under which they live, being resident on an Island they have not the same chance as Indian children living on the mainland, who are constantly mixing with the white people, and who naturally learn the English language more quickly and therefore advance in education more rapidly.

Very few of the children of this Reserve can speak English at all, with the result they are backward in their studies, and are not very interested in school work, if manual training were taught, I consider it
it would be both interesting and instructive, and would help the children to gain useful knowledge more quickly.

With reference to my suggestion for a married man, not past middle age, and one who's wife would be willing to live on the Reserve and help with the work, I consider the moral standards of the people would greatly improve if there were a Missionary and his wife, who were young enough, and energetic enough, to devote part of their time to working among the people and encourage them along the lines of healthful and useful activities.

It appears to me that in the past very little has been done along these lines, with the result that, more especially among the younger people, who having had nothing of interest to occupy their minds, and no decent places of amusement to go to during leisure hours, they have reverted to pastimes that are not beneficial to them.

From experience I find the Indian people are interested and appreciate what is being done along social lines, societies have been formed more especially among the women, and good results are being achieved, but the leadership falls to one or two and what is now needed is more help to carry on this work, this can be secured by the appointment of able and willing Missionary workers.

I understand from Mr. Indian Agent Eade that Christian Island school was built in 1850. At the Fall Fair, September 2nd and 3rd, this building was used as an exhibit hall, and on the second day there was a heavy rainfall. In addition to two or three good-sized streams of water pouring from the ceiling on the tables, rain beat in the sides of the window sashes and poured in at the tops of the windows. Had school been in session it would have been impossible for the children to sit on the east side of the schoolroom. The teacher said he had never seen it like this before, but I feel sure that in any east wind the rain would beat in at the windows.

I made inquiries of the Agent and understand that there are a number of children on the Island who never attend school. I talked with many of the women and some of them were frank in their opinion that the children learn nothing at school and might better be of some use at home. So far as I can ascertain there has never been an Indian of Christian Island pass the Entrance, although many of the young people appear to be bright and interested.

Judging by the number of children of school age, I feel sure that a two room school such as that at Rama is badly needed. The whole reserve would benefit if the teachers appointed were young and interested in sports or welfare work.

Dear Mr. Barner:

An officer of the Department, who has recently returned from Christian Island, is of the opinion that several improvements are necessary in our services there if progress is to be achieved. In the first place, the school building needs replacement, and, as there are nearly 700 children of school age on this reserve - most of whom at the present time are Protestant - the Department is considering the advisability of erecting a 2-classroom school. As far as the teaching services are concerned, I have learned that Mr. Joblin cannot be considered successful. His poor health, doubtlessly, has much to do with his lack of enthusiasm, but the work of your Society and this Department is suffering. I am informed that Mr. Joblin takes practically no interest in reserve affairs generally and his activities as missionary teacher are confined solely to one preaching service per week and to the regular school hours. Much of his time is spent away from the Island altogether, and I know that you would wish to have this information, so that plans can be made for another year.

The suggestion comes to my mind that it might be advisable to conduct an undenominational school of 2 classrooms. There are some Catholic children on the reserve who have attended the school in the past, and this suggests that a school with no church control might be successful in enlisting the cooperation of all on the Island. Father Cadot is the Catholic missionary for the Island. He visits there periodically during the year, and, from what the Department knows of his attitude, I believe that he would be glad to have the members of his flock attend such an institution.

Please discuss this with Mr. Beaton at the first opportunity and let the Department have a recommendation from your Society.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

I beg to enclose a letter written by the Rev. C.C. Dean, of Christian Island, and addressed to you. Mr. Dean in his letter has expressed himself very fully regarding the teaching conditions of the Christian Island Day School at the present time. There is no question but what the school is overcrowded, and that it is almost impossible for a teacher to do full justice to the pupils, apart from the fact there are several more children, possibly about eight who will be of age to commence school this coming term. The present school is full to the limit with desks, and I really do not see how these new pupils can be accommodated unless some other provision can be arranged.

Mr. Dean in his letter has suggested that part of the school classes could be taken in the morning, and the remainder in the afternoon; this arrangement would of course mean that the pupils would not receive the same amount of instruction as they would only be attending half days. The Indian children of Christian Island are very backward owing to the isolation and the fact that they do not mix with the white people, the parents converse in the Indian language, and the children do not commence to learn English until they start to school; consequently it makes it very hard for the teacher to show any progress for the first year or so, you will therefore understand that an arrangement for half day classes would not help the pupils any, and would make it far harder for the teacher.

Mr. Dean is a very good teacher and is very enthusiastic, but I am afraid that he will become discouraged unless some assistance can be given him with his school work. If it is at all possible I would recommend that assistance be given in the appointment of another teacher to take the junior classes, and that the Council Hall be used as a class room for the time being.

I would request that, in preparing his returns in future, he will give the age of each pupil. It is possible that there are a number of children in attendance under 7 years of age. If there is not room to accommodate them, they should remain at home.

The need for extra school accommodation on this reserve has been noted, and it is hoped that Mr. Dean will make the best arrangements possible for carrying on the work during the coming academic year. The Department is not in favour of the half day classes, if same can be avoided.

Christian Island is isolated from the mainland and it is very difficult, at this season of the year, to get a message across. We usually forward telegrams to our agent in care of Dr. Nettleton, who always arranges to have them forwarded to Christian Island at the earliest opportunity. The route to the island from Penetang is to drive by road to Cedar Point, a distance of 16 miles, and then by a smoke signal attract the Indians on the island, 3½ miles distant, who come across in a boat.

Telegrams or communications this season of the year may remain undelivered for several days, as it is entirely unsafe in rough water to cross to the island. No reply has been received from the Agent to our telegram. Mr. Dean's mother resides in Ottawa and she has received no information that her son was operated upon for appendicitis. No doubt, when Mr. Eade receives the message, he will communicate with Mr. Morris and arrange that he take over Mr. Dean's duties.

Reverend Sir,

The Roman Catholic Church authorities have directed attention to the fact that approximately thirty (30) Roman Catholic children have been in attendance at the Christian Island United Church Indian Day School and, consequently, they have expressed a desire for the establishment of a Roman Catholic Day School on the reserve.

The Indian Agent has reported that between twenty-five (25) and thirty (30) children whose parents are recognized as Roman Catholics are in attendance at the present Christian Island School. As it is the intention of the Indian Act that separate educational facilities be provided for Roman Catholic and Protestant children, the Department has decided to give favourable consideration to the establishment of a school for the Roman Catholic Indian children on the Christian Island Reserve. A female teacher is being transferred from another Indian day school to take charge of this new school which will be conducted in the Council Hall, leaving the present school building for the United Church Indian Day School.

With the establishment of this new school, only one teacher will be required at the United Church School and Mr. Vernon Morris, who has been the second teacher at Christian Island for the past year, is being transferred to the Oneida No. 2 Indian Day School.

Instructions are being issued to the Indian Agent to see that children whose parents are recognized as Roman Catholics attend the R. C. School and children whose parents are recognized as Protestants attend the U. C. School. Transfers from one school to the other must not be made without the consent of the Department.

Dear Sir:

Re: Christian Island Indian Day School.

I am sorry that owing to pressure of work I have not been able to visit Christian Island since I returned from the West. I delayed acknowledging receipt of your letter of September 28th, hoping that I might be able to see the situation at first-hand before replying. I was at Christian Island, however, quite recently and Dr. Arthur Barner was there just a few weeks ago, so I think we are fairly well informed in regard to existing conditions.

I would like to call your attention to the correspondence and interviews with officers of the Department of Indian Affairs concerning Christian Island during the last three years.

On September 24th, 1931, a letter was written to Dr. Arthur Barner, our Superintendent of Indian Missions, informing us that an officer of the Department had recently returned from Christian Island and reported that several improvements were necessary if progress was to be achieved; namely, a new school building; a fully qualified teacher in place of Mr. Joblin, who was our nominee at that time; and a second teacher.

In the second paragraph of this letter, you will find a proposal that we should consider an undenominational school of two classrooms. If you will take the time to read the correspondence and to discuss the question with the men who are still in the Department of Indian Education and who were there at that time, you will recognize that the response of the United Church to these suggestions was sincere and co-operative; and on June 15th, Mr. Barner wrote to the Department nominating Rev. Carl C. Dean as the missionary-teacher and said:

"This nomination is made in response to the request of the Department for a young man to take charge of the work on Christian Island. When the time comes for the appointment of a second teacher, we shall be glad to co-operate with you."

From time to time as I visited Ottawa, I impressed upon the Department the necessity of a second teacher, and each time I was informed that there was a Treasury Board ruling rendering it impossible to make new appointments. Imagine our surprise when we...
suddenly received a communication from Mr. Vernon Morris, announcing that he had been appointed second teacher at Christian Island. This is not exactly our conception of co-operation.

That Mr. Dean has made a great success of his work on the Island needs no comment. The very fact that for the first time in the history of the school there were pupils in an entrance class speaks eloquently of the confidence which the Indians have come to have in him and his leadership.

In view of this history, we were certainly unprepared for your communication of September 28th, informing us that the pupils were being separated according to denominational affiliation; that a Roman Catholic teacher was being appointed, etc. Evidently, the price of sincere co-operation with the Department of Indian Affairs at the present time in the improvement of personnel and teaching methods is to be completely disregarded. The more earnestly one tries to improve the technique and efficiency of the educational work under the direction of the United Church, the less he is consulted about changes which are in contemplation by the Department.

I wish to state emphatically that, if the Chief and Councillors of Christian Island have come to the conclusion that in justice to the minority there should be one Roman Catholic teacher, the United Church would welcome the opportunity of co-operating in a public school where, for example, the new appointee would teach the junior grades and the present teacher, Mr. Dean, the senior grades, the pupils being separated for half an hour a day according to denominational affiliation for religious instruction. As it is at present, Mr. Dean finds himself left with 44 children in 11 classes and cannot possibly teach successfully the course of study outlined by the Ontario Department of Education.

I realise that it is probably too late to protest, but I speak for the Board of Home Missions of the United Church when I say that we feel very keenly the injustice of the method which has been followed in the making of these changes at Christian Island.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Dr. McGill:

Re: Christian Island Indian Day School.

I desire to make formal application to the Department of Indian Affairs for the appointment of a second teacher to the United Church Day School on Christian Island, and submit the following for your consideration:

(1) The present teacher, Rev. C. C. Dean, has forty-four children in eleven classes, making quite impossible any kind of effective work. Dear Sir:

Re: Christian Island Indian Day School

I would like to call the attention of the Government to the great need of a new day school for the housing of the United Church children on Christian Island. This matter has been under discussion between the Church and the Department of Indian Affairs for at least six years. When I first discussed it with Mr. Russell Ferrier, the Superintendent of Indian Education, he asked me not to press the matter, in order that the Government might have time to explore the possibility of building a two-roomed school which would be directly under the Department. He said he was well aware that the old building which is now being used as the junior classroom was no credit to the Government.

When the additional teacher was later appointed, we made temporary arrangements with the Chief and Council to house the senior class in the Council House. The arrangement is unsatisfactory for reasons which are self-evident.

We understand that the Government is now proceeding to build for the minority group on Christian Island a new school and teacherage. The idea of establishing a school which would be directly under the Department has therefore been definitely abandoned. It is obviously unfair that the Church which has given religious leadership to the Indians on Christian Island for more than a hundred years and conducted a day school for their children for many years before the Department of Indian Affairs assumed any responsibility for the teacher's salary, should be expected to accept the type of accommodation which has been provided for its classrooms, on the plea that the Government has no money to erect new buildings, while the minority group, whose presence on the Island is of comparatively recent date, should be able to secure a new school building and teacherage. This is not a criticism of the decision to build a school for the minority. Once the decision has been made to appoint a teacher they are undoubtedly entitled to the necessary building and equipment.
I am therefore writing to ask, on behalf of the United Church, that in the Estimates which are presented to Parliament for the fiscal year, beginning April 1st, an amount should be included for a new two-roomed school and teacherage on Christian Island. I think the way in which we have carried on for several years under the handicaps mentioned above is an indication of our willingness to co-operate with the Department of Indian Affairs, but we are firmly convinced that the time has come when for this and other reasons, which need not be enumerated, we ought to have a new building. This is particularly true in view of the fact that the Government now apparently has money to spend on new buildings.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Extract from letter of Frank J. Joblin
to the Prime Minister,
November 26th, 1936.

"I explained to you that having given my life to the work of Missionary Teacher among the Indians, I had no special preparation for any other work, and when left without a position, or any provision for the future after twenty-two years service, I began working out on farms and have been following that work for the past five years.

"I don't object to hard work, but at my age, being over fifty, it is rather strenuous, and the wages are so small that only the bare necessities of life can be had. This year there is a doctor's bill of twenty-five dollars to pay, and our eleven year old lad (our only child) requires work done to his teeth which the dentist says will cost around thirty dollars. Professional men don't seem to realize that a poor man can't afford to pay the prices they demand.

"I have education enough for any ordinary position and there must be plenty of jobs in the gift of the Government that I could do acceptably. With my experience with the Indians I could have qualified admirably for the position of Indian Agent on some Reservation but the Department was not willing to give me any such chance.

"I would much prefer working if any suitable work can be had, but if not, don't you think some sort of yearly allowance could be arranged, because teaching in Government schools did not place one in line for the usual pension or superannuation."

Dear Dr. Moore:

Re-educational system at Christian Island.

In my opinion, the extensive sickness on Christian Island is due to malnutrition. The inhabitants seem helpless and do not sufficiently exert themselves to help themselves. I do not suppose anything much can be done to help the adults but it seems to me that a change in the educational system would help the children. The present system of teaching is similar to that in other parts of the province and I doubt if it is adapted to the Indians who are mentally under-par. I have studied the educational system used in the Mental Hospital for children at Orillia. It is very practical and helps the children to make a living for themselves. I feel sure that, if we procured a teacher from the Orillia Mental Hospital, the children would become an asset rather than a liability as they are now.

Yours very truly,

Dear Doctor Tanner:

Your letter of the first instant, addressed to Dr. Moore, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

It is scarcely necessary to state that I appreciate very fully your interest in the educational courses provided at the Christian Island Indian day schools and your anxiousness to have these courses improved.

We intimated, in a circular sent out about three years ago, that at least one third of the regular study period should be devoted to vocational instruction and it is gratifying to be able to report that most of our teachers have brought their courses of study into conformity with our wishes.

I am reasonably familiar with the courses of study provided at mental hospitals and at the institutions established for the care of subnormal boys and girls, and I am aware also that these courses of study have been improved during the last five or six year period. I am not at all sure, however, that it would be wise to adopt such a course at any of our schools until a careful survey had been made by a psychiatrist of the I.Q. standing of the pupils. If the teachers in charge of the schools at Christian Island are sufficiently interested, they will experience little difficulty in securing the services of an official of the Ontario Department of Education to make -

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to allowing the teachers of the Christian Island Schools to take the Easter holiday leave in March, rather than at the regular time, owing to travelling conditions to and from the island.

Generally speaking, the Department does not favour taking holidays at other than the prescribed times. Part of the object in operating schools on a reserve is to train the children in matters of punctuality and make them recognize that fair rules, issued for the guidance of all, must be followed. To allow special favours, such as that requested by the teachers of the Christian Island schools, makes it appear to the Indians as if we are operating the schools for the benefit of the teachers rather than for the benefit of the pupils. With these thoughts in mind, I am extremely sorry that the teachers saw fit to ask for this special privilege. However, if they so desire, they may take the Easter holiday period during the dates mentioned in your letter, on the distinct understanding that they will be back on duty on March 26.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa

I hesitate to complain, and I really do not intend to do so. But I feel that it is my responsibility to report this matter. For some time I have felt that all is not well with things at the United Church School.

This came to a climax when I read to Mr. Stephens your letter regarding the vacation period allowed for Easter. He more or less feels that he confering an honour upon the Dept. by teaching here, and said that the job doesn't a thing to him; this remark was brought about when I pointed out to him the necessity of punctuality being taught Indians.

He has never been very particular about starting on time, nor does he allow the children their regular recess time. Just yesterday I was coming past the school, when he called me in to discuss a little matter, the children were still out playing. I asked him what time it was; it was then 3:20 PM. I drew this to his attention, and he made some remark about the children doing something and had detained him from calling them back to their work, all I could see them doing was that some were playing cards.

I really believe that he is satisfied, but Mrs. Stephens is not at all so, she misses the social life, and quite frankly say so.

I realize the difficulty of replacement of teachers, but surely there is someone that is familiar with Indians, and Indian education that we could employ.

I have hesitated for some time to make this report, but when one comes out and distinctly states that a job doesn't mean a thing, what other inference is one to arrive at, than that they are not satisfied with the position.

I am making this report with the idea in mind, that if you deem it advisable for a change to be made, you will have ample to do so.

We have two children of our own going to school, and naturally we are anxious to have them get an education. I know that you will treat this as confidential.

G. E. Hurl, A/Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Rev. C. C. Dean, teacher of the Christian Island Indian Day School, was ill during part of the December quarter, and, while he was absent from the school, Mr. Vernon H. Morris was employed as substitute teacher for 22 days (November 6th to November 27th). Authority for Mr. Morris' engagement was received from the office of the Superintendent General.

In the case of a teacher who has been in our employ more than a year, it has been the practice of the Department, in the past, to allow reasonable sick leave with pay. No definite length of sick leave has ever been adopted, and, in the majority of cases in the past, when a teacher has been sick, the school has remained closed and no substitute engaged.

In view of our past procedure, I consider that Mr. Dean should be paid in full for the December quarter, and I would appreciate your approval.

Ottawa, 15th February, 1912.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 13th instant, I re-enclose herewith the accounts which you submitted from Mr Geo. E. Gendron, Mr P.A. McDonald and Mr M.A. Gendron, respectively. You will observe that they have been attached to voucher forms. All accounts should be dealt with in this manner before being sent to the Department for payment. You will notice that the name of the band (Christian Island) has been written on the upper right hand corner of each voucher. As the expenditure is incurred on behalf of that band it is proper for the name to appear thereon. (In the case of relief vouchers, etc., the name of the band to which the Indian receiving the supplies belongs, should also be stated on the voucher). In this instance the expenditure was incurred on behalf of the school, and consequently the words "For School" have been written thereon.

Kindly sign the printed certificate at the foot of each voucher form and return to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Seating can be greatly improved by a new arrangement of the desks and the purchase of six new backs. By the present arrangement, it is little better than double desks. On the outside of the room, they have two rows of single desks about six or eight inches apart. Instead of seven rows as now, they could have four outside rows having 9 desks and 2 rows having 4 or 5 desks each. Chairs are a poor substitute for backs.
Ottawa, June 13, 1931.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Christian Island Indian Day School, states that the seating can be greatly improved by a re-arrangement of the desks. He states that, instead of seven rows of desks as at present, the desks should be arranged in four outside rows, each having nine desks, and two rows in the centre, having four or five desks in each, and that, when the desks are so arranged, rear seats should be provided.

I have to request that, during the coming summer holidays, you will have the desks re-arranged, as recommended by the Inspector. After this has been done, please inform the Department of the size of each rear desk in each row and also the name of the manufacturer of the desks, when the Department will consider ordering six rear seats - one for each row of desks. The name of the manufacturer of the desks will, no doubt, be stamped in the metal part of the desk, as well as the size of the rear desk in each row. The Inspector states that the present seating arrangement is little better than double desks; as on the outside of the room there are two rows about 6 or 8 inches apart.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

H. J. Eade, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Christian Island,
Ont.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, relative to the purchase of fuel and repairs to the lavatories and desks at the Christian Island Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of approximately 6 cords of 24" wood for the school. You should see that a good grade of the full quantity of wood is supplied, and the cost should not exceed approximately $4.50 per cord.

An order is being forwarded the Government Stationery Office here to supply the classroom material considered necessary, with the exception of the teacher's desk, a thermometer, a water pail and a clock. Sir,

I beg to enclose an account in favour of the Tessier Tanning Mill, Penetang, Ont. to the sum of $70.99, for tables and cupboard supplied in connection with the fitting up of a second classroom for the Christian Island Day School, held at present in the Community Hall. The purchase of this equipment was made necessary because of the fact that since the appointment of Mr Vernon Morris as assistant teacher, eleven new beginners have been added to the school roll, making the total now on the register sixty nine, forty four are of junior grades and are taught by Mr Morris in the School house, the remaining twenty five are of senior grades and taught by the principle Mr Dean in the Community Hall. Owing to the increase in the number of pupils all desks with the exception of seven are now in use in the school house. The object of securing tables was that, the hall is constantly in used for community purposes after school hours and tables could be moved away better than desks which would have to be screwed to the floor, each table accommodates five pupils. With reference to the cupboard this is very necessary as there is no suitable cupboard room in the hall, and as there are numerous books and other small equipment which have to be looked after carefully it is essential that they be put away at the end of each day and locked up in a safe place. In the event of a new school being built at Christian Island at some future date this equipment could be transferred and used to advantage. I would recommend this account be paid.

Memorandum:

Chrisitan Island U. C. Day School

Some repairs are needed badly here. The belfry is pulling away from the building leaving a gap of about three inches. In a heavy wind it is liable to collapse with serious results. It should be braced securely with heavy wire or iron braces. Snap of belfry attached.

The woodshed attached to the rear wall of the building is giving way, pulling the siding with it and making the class room draughty and cold. It needs to be jacked up and nailed into place.

These repairs can be done by local Indian labour.

Two pieces of blackboard 9" each with frame and chalk trough, also four window shades for the class-room are needed badly.

Inspector.
Ottawa, November 12, 1934.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited Christian Island, has drawn attention to the repairs required to the United Church School on the reserve. He states the belfry is pulling away from the building, leaving a gap of about three inches, and that in a heavy wind it is liable to collapse. He recommends that it be braced securely with heavy wire or iron braces. He also reports that the woodshed attached to the rear wall of the building is giving away, pulling the siding with it and making the classroom draughty and cold. This woodshed requires to be jacked up and nailed into place. The Inspector states that the repairs to the belfry and the woodshed can be done by local Indian labour.

I would therefore request that you arrange, as soon as possible, to have the work carried out. If any materials are required, you should purchase same and have the Indians perform the labour. After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for labour and material.

The Inspector states, further, that four window shades are required for the classroom. You may purchase and have installed four shades of the size required.

Two pieces of blackboard, with chalk trough and mouldings, will be ordered through the Government Stationery Office, to be shipped to you, Penetanguishene, Ont. When this material arrives, you should arrange to have it taken to the school and set up in the classroom. Any expenditure in connection with the installing of the blackboard will be paid upon receipt of a certified voucher, in triplicate.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. A. Allan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Christian Island,
Ont.

MEMORANDUM

Minister's Office

June 10, 1935.

DR. McGILL:

Will you kindly furnish draft reply to the attached from Mr. J. R. L. Starr, K.C. (June 6) in which the suggestion is made that a new two-roomed school be provided for the Protestant pupils of Christian Island, and a residence for the Principal, the Rev. Mr. Deas.

Private Secretary.
MEMORANDUM

June 17/

Mr. Churchill

This was returned with the draft letter to Mr. Starr.

Do you want it for your files?

K.O.
Ottawa, June 14, 1935.

Dear Mr. Starr:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the request of the Indians of the Christian Island Band, for the erection of a two-roomed school building and teachers' residence, for the benefit of the Indian children whose parents are members of the United Church of Canada.

Owing to pressing demands for the erection of school buildings, on reserves where there is no provision for educational facilities, it was not found possible to provide the funds required to erect a new school building for the Protestant children at Christian Island. It is intended to erect a building for the Roman Catholic children, as there are no adequate school facilities for the children of that faith.

While the present school facilities for the Protestant children are also inadequate, yet, I would point out that this school has been carrying on under similar conditions for several years, and their requirements are not so pressing as in the case of the Catholic school. The need of a new two-roomed school building for the Protestant children will be kept in mind and an effort made to obtain the funds necessary to erect a suitable building when our Estimates for the next fiscal year are in course of preparation. We were unable to obtain any part of the appropriation under the Public Works Construction Act to carry out a building programme which included the erection of a school for the Protestant children at Christian Island.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

April 1st, 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. J. M. Wardle, Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch.

Provision has been made in the Special Supplementary Estimates for the present fiscal year for the amount of $7,500., to be used in the erection of a new day school on the Christian Island Indian Reserve, Christian Island Agency, Ontario, to replace the present Christian Island United Church Indian Day School.

This should be a two-roomed school, with accommodation in each room for thirty-five (35) pupils. There should be a full basement, part of which it is desired to use for manual training work. There should also be living accommodation in this building for two teachers. This will mean a living room, a kitchen and two bedrooms.

This Division would appreciate your giving the above matter immediate attention.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

APPROVED:

Director.

Dear Sir:

The Department does not consider it advisable to place a belfrey on an Indian school. Experience shows that a belfrey is a continual source of expense, as frequent repairs have to be made to the roof in the vicinity of the belfrey.

Under these circumstances it has been decided not to place a belfrey on any day school building in future.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT made by W.R. McVittie
on the Christian Island Day School,

Dated: October 29, 1937.
Original on file 6-1-6A.

I had the privilege of seeing the new school in process
of construction. When completed it will provide a quite
modern type of accommodation for the teacher and pupils.
I was particularly pleased with the splendid lighting
facilities, and the provision for cloak-rooms.

More blackboard space would be an advantage, I consider;
and I do not think that adequate provision has been made for
proper ventilation. The Teacher's desk set on a platform
is not in conformity with modern Educational thought, and it
is most regrettable that better play-ground facilities have
not been provided. I am rather disappointed, too, that
basement rooms have not been provided where, besides affording
a playroom in inclement weather, provision could be made for
instruction in handicrafts, cooking, sewing, manual training,
etc. It is my conviction that the objectives of educational
effort in this community should be to train the boys and girls
to meet the ordinary problems of living, rather than to drill
scholastic formulae which they will probably never use.
EX'D.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter 6-1-5 of January 3rd, 1941 authorizing the hot drink for the months of January and February in the R.C. and U.C. schools. When school started it was impossible to secure milk on the Island. Consequently I purchased milk in the canned form at Cedar Point bearing in mind that the expenditure was not to exceed 10¢ per day per room.

In Mr. McCracken's letter of December the 28th, 1940 March the first was suggested as the date of termination for serving this hot drink. I discussed the matter with Mr. McCracken and he says that he intended to have the request cover the month of March also.

I have taken the matter up with the three school teachers concerned and it is their wish to serve the hot drink during the month of March also. As March is one of our winter months I would greatly appreciate the extension till April 1st, as in former years. Can this extension be made?

Christian Island, Ont.,
December 13, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Authority has been given by W.S. Arneil, Inspector of Indian Agencies, to have a door cut between the two classrooms in the U.C. school. This has been needed since the school was built as it has always been necessary for teachers and pupils to get to either classroom by going through the Residence or around the outside; both were very inconvenient.

It seems reasonable to expect that the door would cost in the neighbourhood of $8 to $10. Then, of course, there would be the door frame, and the labour for putting it in. I would say that the approximate cost would be $20.00.

In checking the condition of the school I find that there are other minor repairs needed which should be done at the same time — such repairs as to window leaks, door locks etc. Only in one case has any damage been due to a pupil and that was only a small window in the toilet house.

I would estimate that the entire cost including labour, would not exceed $30.00, and I would recommend making the necessary repairs.

I trust that The Dep't will see fit to grant the above-mentioned expenditure and that authority may be given as soon as possible so that the work may be done during the Christmas holidays.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Br.,
Ottawa.

Yours truly,

Acting Indian Agent, Christian Island,
Ont.

Each year it has been the custom for the Teachers of our schools to make hot Cocoa drinks for the children during the winter months. We have felt that this procedure is splendid in that the hot drink each morning seems to give the children the much-needed energy.

I would recommend that, if possible, hot drinks be again granted from now until Easter.

Estimation of supplies are as follows:

3 tins canned milk (condensed) per day
25 lbs. cocoa per month
30 lbs. sugar per month
3 lbs. salt for flavouring entire period

(The above estimations are for all three schoolrooms, supplies would be divided accordingly)

Condensed milk is preferable at approximately $10 per can, because of sanitation --- also as a general rule there is not enough extra fresh milk on the Island to supply the schools each day.

I would suggest that 100 lb. bag of sugar be purchased and if any were left over it could be kept for the next winter. The cocoa may be purchased in bulk.

I trust that the Dep't. will see fit to grant this expenditure.

I am,
Your Obedient Servant,

Acting Indian Agent,
Christian Island, Ont.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Br.,
Ottawa.

Now, about the split peas, you could do what you think best. If you think the children should have them, Sister will be glad to prepare the soup. We leave it to your judgment.
